description:
4 stars for the pho. everything else is in the fine print.

Stumbled upon this little hole in the wall pho place while walking between Costco and BBB. Stopped in for some pho and would say the flavor is some of the best I've had in SF! 

I'm a regular for #32 pho w/beef flank and an order of imperial/egg rolls. There can be some variation on flavor and quality/cut/thickness of meat, but overall its pretty solid. In particular, the cut of flank is pretty tender, has some tendon, and the soup has a really good flavor to it. 

The place is a bit of a hole in the wall, and everything is pretty dated. Service can be hit or miss since there are only two people that can take your order. Sometimes I come on Saturday at opening, and have to sit there for 15-20 min because owners are stuck in traffic and running late. When they do arrive tho, they are very attentive and quick to get food out. Overall I'm a fan, and I've been hitting this place up weekly!
author: James S.

description:
Dropped in for lunch last Saturday. What happened?

Had the Bun beef bowl; everything was ok, except the beef, i could see it was a few days old. Why use old meat? Save some money? C'mon, you can do better. 
Bad customer experience for $10.50.
author: Bert K.

description:
On 3/30/2018 while I was arrived in the city of San Francisco, CA, I headed to this local Vietnamese restaurant right at the South of Market neighborhood called, "Pho Hour." Formerly named as "Sunrise Cafe," Pho Hour serves the customers of all ages to taste their authentic Vietnamese cuisines every year from pho to banh mi right at your comfort zone. The atmosphere is much active and ongoing as I welcomed there. The concept is much like visiting to your local cafe in the U.S. although it's much spacious and wide filled with basic designs and classic 20th Century flare across the whole interior room.

The employees here from servers, counters and cookers are doing a great job for making the customers like me a tremendous service during in a busier lunch hour environment. No cons.

Now onto the food! I ordered one of my favorite Vietnamese cuisines called, "Pho Tai" aka Rare Steak Vermicelli Noodle Soup. As I ate it, that pho tasted very good! The broth was perfectly rich and bold thanks to the aroma of spices and seasonings. The rest of the toppings from onions, scallions, and rare steak were perfectly fresh and elegant which I'm very enjoying it. The steak did boiled and cooked perfectly on a hot broth and it was perfectly eatable to chew my teeth properly. Not a bad pho at all on a lunch break in SF.

Parking at Pho Hour can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface metered street parking if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Pho Hour is a fine and well maintained local Vietnamese restaurant that I've ever discovered for the first time in San Francisco. Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering. Well visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: I work a block away and I've tried 90% of their menu by now. It is my go-to spot if I didn't bring my own lunch. My dad grew up in Vietnam until the war, so he introduced a lot of Vietnamese dishes to me. Food here is solid, the noodle soups are so comforting on a cold day. I love the bun rieu and seafood soups. The hainan chicken rice, crab fried rice, and garlic noodles are also great. Sometimes it gets busy during lunchtime but just call ahead to put in the order for to-go. Staff is not chatty but they're friendly. Get the Vietnamese coffee if you need that sweet tasty yet stronger caffeine
author: Chin L.

description:
If a restaurant has 'Pho' in its name, chances are pretty good that you should order it at least as your introduction to the place. That piece of common wisdom never did resonate with me because I'm such a rebel. Yeah, I'm talking about me, dammit. Anyway, I came here late one afternoon as I was strolling to Trader Joe's and noticed they served a Hai Nam Chicken with Rice for $10.60. I ordered it because I'm a rebel. Certainly not because the place looked like a culinary hotbed for audaciously prepared poultry. It looked more like a courthouse lunchroom furnished with overstock from the Office Depot (photo: http://bit.ly/2r7KnKx). The plate was clean but underwhelming with the chopped chicken straight from the fridge and the shoyu-drenched rice threatening to overtake the plate (photo: http://bit.ly/2JBw48t). Not exciting but not inedible either. Pho sho.

FOOD - 3 stars...fast food version of Hainan chicken
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...worn down but kept clean enough
SERVICE - 3 stars...owner was friendly
TOTAL - 3 stars...maybe I should come back for the pho
author: Ed U.

description: Solid bowl of pho! I walked in half an hour before closing on a Thursday night and Pho Hour's combo pho was just what I needed on that chilly evening. The broth was flavorful and full of flank steak, tendon, and meatballs. Don't expect anything fancy at this establishment, but it is a delicious quick meal with plentiful parking nearby- what more could you need?
author: Chloe Z.

description:
Came here after the ultimate rejection (Costco wouldn't let us eat at their food court without a member card). Though we entered dejected and downtrodden, we left uplifted and unbreakable.

Everything about this place is exactly you want out of a casual pho experience. The pho is hearty and plentiful with meat, and the service is incredibly quick and pleasant. Though there's nothing much to speak of in terms of decor or ambiance, the quality of the food itself makes everything else pale in terms of importance.

I will definitely be back here again and again.
author: Jenny D.

description:
I should have read the reviews. Don't get the Pho the meat is as bad as others have mentioned.
The spring rolls were not fresh and service was extremely slow.  The tables were not bussed I guess this is the place you go when there are no other choices.
author: John N.

description:
My little Vietnamese haven near work! My coworkers and I love this place for a quick lunch. I've only tried the iced Vietnamese coffee (they give you the drip thing so the coffee is being made in front of you on your table) which was delicious and definitely gave me a kick (but not crazy, crazy strong) and the chicken vermicelli bowl. Soooo tasty, drooling just thinking of it now! They definitely get it right here.

They're pretty straight forward and don't beat around the bush with small talk, but super nice people working here. 

I will for sure be back! I actually tried to go again this past Wednesday, but they had a sign that they were closed to fix their equipment. So hopefully we'll meet again soon! :)
author: Melanie W.

description: Very good and super nice owners. No wonder this place has such a loyal following during lunch time. I got pho which was absolutely what I needed at the moment but practically everyone was ordering their chicken bahn mi. Must be delicious! Have to stop by when I'm in the area again and try it out.
author: Offset M.

description: 2 stars mostly for the coffee... my rice plate i found a rubber band in the dish, it was on top of my pork skin... the one who prepare the dish didnt check the dish before pass on to the waiter, the waiter didnt take a 2nd look after giving the dish to the customer... but everything is come to the dish if its good people will come back... my opinion the rice is too dry... felt like old cooked rice... egg was good... no comment on the eggs... the pork chop didnt like it much...
author: Michael P.

description:
When there's laughter coming out of the kitchen you know the food is going to be the biggity bomb! Also pay attention to the specials on their chalkboard, today's duck noodle soup was especially on point. 
FYI: To go containers @ .25 each
author: eVa J.

description: Ordered the spicy beef phone and it was  pretty good. Tender beef, good taste and spice, good quantity, and I feel i got my money's worth. I take off a star as I feel the salt was on the high side. Would've been better to provide salt and keep the quantity low. This is a no frills place that does well with their main food.
author: Mackie M.

description: I really wanted to like this place since my housemate kept raving about it, but when I went to order the Pho Tai Bo Vien, the broth was more on the bland side and it was kinda just alright.  I prefer my noodles more on the al dente side and I felt like the noodles were cooked longer than I would've preferred.  She said it's an off day as they normally have more flavorful broth and better noodles, so maybe it's just one of their bad days.  The broth is really a make it or break it for me but given she's been here a gajillion times, I'm willing to give this place a second try.
author: Carena N.

description: Everyone likes a compliment. There's nothing wrong with calling them up and letting them know that you had a great experience. It is also nice to say something positive about your experience to the manager while you are at the restaurant.
author: Hugo B.

description:
I was looking forward to eating at this restaurant and brought my friend who had a service animal, which is entirely legal to have in the state of California , and we were rudely treated and told to be in the back of the restaurant. We were then told again to move and we refused as we do not want to be treated like vagrants or discriminated because of the dog. 
The dog is trained to be protective , it is a registered service animal. I hope the management can understand and be inclusive of such customers.
author: Shawn S.

description:
I just checked in here for the 70th time.  Why?  For a few reasons

The meatball pho is extremely consistent.  The beef broth is tastey and the pork banh mi is fabulous.

Tradition.  My son, partner and I have made this our Saturday lunch.  We get to just catch  up and have family time.

Great owners.  The husband and wife always greet us with a warm hello.  This is by no means a fancy place.  But these two always make you feel welcomed.  

The owner always just asks one thing.  "Do you want the same thing?".   We just nod yes.  This includes the modification to the orders and our favorite chilis and hot sauce brought to the table.

Don't judge this place because it isn't trendy or modern decor.  Don't complain about the price as it is NOT expensive. (yes a bit more than other pho places but then consider the cost of SF.)  Parking on Saturday is super easy.    

This  Mom and Pop place is just perfect for us living in a city.  

This is a can't go wrong place
author: James W.

description: Love this place! Their pho is super flavorful yet not heavy. The family who owns this place is just lovely as well! However, their Bun Bo Hue is slightly bland in my opinion ): Everything else is delicious though! Love their bah mi and vermicelli plates as well!
author: Mandy H.

description: This is a really solid pho place that I'm not sure how folks don't know about. I ordered a takeout Pho Ga (chicken soup) and it was great.  My only complaint was that the portion was smaller than other Pho places I've been to, but honestly you typically get too much pho so i'm nitpicking here. I'd definitely go back and try the beef phos and other things.
author: Gieselle A.

description:
Affordable Vietnamese food in this part of the SOMA. It doesn't wow you but it will fill your hunger. 

My friends got pho and said it was decent. I got the #11 (grilled pork with vermicelli noodles), and I thought it was okay, as well. They also serve banh mi sandwiches and rice plates. You order at the counter, and the menu and food photos are on the wall. (They also have a regular menu). 

Prices are around $8- $11, so you can't complain much. Friendly service at this hole-in-the-wall.
author: Joanna L.

description:
This places looks ghetto!

We found this place on Yelp--since it was the closet Vietnamese pho places on our map, we decided to try it. Turns out, it was pretty hard to find. Even when we arrived, we didn't see the place, because it had giant metal gates on the door--we thought it was residential unit and not a commercial store!

Once inside, the place looks pretty run down. Really old furniture, overall not very clean. The price is also quite high (more than $10 for a bowl of pho), given the lack of decor. Definitely not a place to get cheap pho.

The food portions are pretty big, above average in terms of pho portions. The quality is also not bad, pretty authentic pho. The broth is ok. Not bad, but nothing to rave about. The wait time took a while--not fast, and not too slow.

Overall, a pretty average pho place charging high prices.
author: Henry L.

description: Not the most luxurious place but it's very wholesome and the people are super nice! Great food too and at a very reasonable price. Support immigrant businesses !
author: Albert D.

description:
Found this on Yelp as the nearest Vietnamese restaurant to my company.

Had special beef pho in this what we would call fly-restaurant in China since flies will flies will fly around you while you eat.

What's disappointing is that the pho here is not special or amazingly yum as most fly restaurants do in China.

What I like about my Combo #30 beef noodle soup is that beef slices, beef balls, tendons and cartilages were plenty and all very tasty.
author: Ziyao T.

description:
Tried coming here for lunch but spent so much time in the line that half my lunch was over before I was even able to place my order. 

Like the previous place, I do not know how people can come here for lunch.
author: M C.

description: Loved this place! Super casual and great place to just walk in when you need a quick fix of Vietnamese food. You know it's legit when they have the drip Vietnamese coffee! The staff was also really sweet and friendly and made us feel just at home. Will be taking my parents there soon when they visit and can't wait to see what they think!
author: Christine L.

description:
Date of Dining: July 9th
Table for 2
Time: Lunch

At first glance: Well, there isn't much to look at from the outside, reminds me of pit stop for workers who want a quick lunch for the go. Needless to say once inside it's not very appealing to the eye. But again was not expecting it to be, just wanted a hearty homemade meal. Their menu appears to be very large and divers.

Ambiance: Inside a few people were seated very casual and hipsters. Kind of gloomy to me..maybe the windows need cleaned and some music. 

Presentation: The food presentation was nothing special. 

Ordered:
Com Suon nuong
Bun gia gio thit nuong

Taste:
Bun gia gio thit nuong - was perfect! Crunchy and full of flavor I would recommend this dish. 

I did see some prior reviewer complaints regarding the .50 cent difference on menu prices... however this has no effect on my review, but I just wanted to put it out there that maybe one should take into consideration that this restaurant appears to be family run and they are probably not making much of a profit to afford major changes such as to their menus. But overall the food was good.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Why do some people think that just because a place is a hole in the wall, that it is ok for the restaurant to sacrifice cleanliness? That is such a poor mentality. 

Cleanliness should be number one.

When I go out to eat Pho, I never expect it to match my mom's cooking. But I'm mostly concerned with freshness and cleanliness. When I received my bowl of Pho, I noticed a few noodles that were yellow. At first I just figured that they had accidentally put some of the yellow noodles into my bowl and so it was a mix of the two. Then I realized that this wasn't the case. A good portion of my pho noodles had TURNED YELLOW. I asked the restaurant and they apologized and said it was because it was the batch from yesterday. 

First of all, WTF.. noodles from yesterday? Talk about fresh.

Second of all, I've had leftover Pho and have never ever seen the noodles turn yellow. I suspect it had been more than a day.

He gave me another bowl but at that point, how can you enjoy your food knowing this is the quality of ingredients that are going in?

You guys need to wake up.
author: Tony P.

description: Hole in a wall place, easy to walk by and never visit, but good pho. Best I've tried so far in SF.  Need to try the ban mi next time.
author: Gordon L.

description: This place is now called Sunrise Cafe, btw. Anyway, they have the best banh mi sandwich I have ever had. I've had both the chicken and the pork, and both are phenomenal. The bread is perfect and delicious -- crunchy, but not too crunchy, on the outside, tender on the inside. Perfect amount of sauce, pickled carrot, and super fresh jalapeño and cilantro. And the meat is incredible. A super tasty, well balanced sandwich. I've had plenty of banh mi at other establishments, and they've been good, but never as great as these. And the place is super unassuming. Half the lights are off every time I come in, and it's always a little empty looking. But don't let that deter you. The food is awesome, the service is friendly, and the price is cheap.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Still open!  They did a partial rebrand to "Pho Hour," though you'll see all the signage inside, including menus, still says Sunrise Cafe. Same menu, same owners, same prices, same location, etc.  

I come here often, but just for Vietnamese sandwiches, which are sooo good! Quick, cheap delicious!
 
Easy street parking on Bryant and Dore. Just a block from Costco.
author: Greg B.

description:
The Pho tasted good, I mean it really did. Tasted excellent... + 4

But, the rubbery bumpy white things; are they meat or are they plastic? -2

Also, good looking out on the siracha. +1
author: James N.

description:
Love this mom & pop shop! Pay no heed to people complaining about prices like we're not in SOMA. Affordable, simple, delicious homemade Viet food. Rich, tasty pho and fresh, filling rice dishes. 

Gets busy around lunch since it's just one family running the whole restaurant. It's a true fam-owned business, and I always see the owners work every day from start to close - and they're just the friendlist people ever. One feels good about eating here. 

The place is real casual - no frills, just the essentials - real solid spot for a quick, casual lunch if you're in the area.
author: Anna H.

description: So legit!! I love everything I've gotten here.  Actually left a review when they used to be Sunrise cafe but since they changed their name I gotta write another one.  Oh and the nicest guy works in the front.  I even clean up after myself sometimes because he's so nice lol.
author: Chi N.

description: Grungy hole-in-the-wall place. Was a little worried about quality when I walked in. Very quickly disabused of my concerns. Excellent pho and Vietnamese coffee!
author: Ope O.

description:
There's something really comforting about a big bowl of spicy beef noodle soup on Saturday morning. There are no long lines, no crowds, just a peaceful bowl of soup and the bustle of the owners doing their work. Efficient and Friendly service is a plus too. It's my little secret so don't let the word get around too quickly.

IT IS OPEN!!!!
author: Cindy J.

description: Got the chicken pho, lacked flavor, soggy noodles and bland chicken. Usually things tastes better when I'm hungry but this place didn't do it for me at all.
author: Raymond P.

description: Simple ambiance, rich broth, bahn mi sandwiches to-go (bbq pork is my go to)
author: Peter H.

description: Really wide selection of pho and plate meals. Prices are very reasonable; within $8 - 12 dollars for a meal. I ordered the pho with raw steak and meatballs, and it was very good! The broth was delicious. To spice it up, I added sriracha and hoisin sauce (both available at the restaurant), and that just brought it to the next level! I plan on coming back and trying out the rest of the pho on their menu.
author: Jen A.

description:
Let's be honest with ourselves here, this place should be named "Sunset Café" and not "Sunrise". 
Its dimly lit inside while natural light is desperately trying to peer though the barred out windows.
Outside, police sirens, frustrated drivers honking and the sound of homeless men urinating on the wall fill the air.

Walking by, I honestly thought they were closed. Not closed for the day, but closed indefinitely.
A small, neon "open" sign gave me hope as I pulled back the heavy jail-like door into a Vietnamese/burger/breakfast contraption.

As a dine-in option, you are asked to be seated and given the option of hot tea in an 8oz cup or water.... I chose the former.

Price points are higher than those in little Saigon, but you come to expect that in SoMa.

Opted for the banh mi thit nuong (bbq pork Vietnamese sandwich - $5.50) and the Bun Cha Gio Thit Nuong (BBQ pork and egg roll with vermicelli - $8.75).

The banh mi was large and packed with meat/flavor. Easily large enough for two. Tip: ask for extra butter as it can be a tad bit dry.
The vermicelli was HUGE and, like the sandwich, loaded with meat and flavor. 

The inside leaves more to be desired, but you come for the food.... Not the ambiance. Service was quick and friendly and they take card.
All in all, pull over while in traffic and treat yoself to this hole in the wall... totally worth the detour.

 tip: they close at 7:30pm
author: Ryan L.

description: They used to called Sunrise Cafe. I come to this restaurant very often. I love their food and services. Owner is very sweet and the food is great. Also, their price is fair for the food quality. They had remodeled their restaurant not too long ago to make it more comfortable for their customers. This place is good for to-go or eat in. I have not try their breakfast menu at all, so I have no comment, but this place is a great for lunch and early dinner.
author: Kelly H.

description: Why does this place get so much love for 'meh' pho? My guess is it has to do with there being no other pho choices in the direct area of a somewhat bustling business/commercial spot. However, I came in the hours after normal bustle and hustle so maybe that wasn't quite the Pho hour. Jokes aside, my Bun Bo Hue didn't resemble any other Bun Bo Hue I'd had before and the Pho my wife had looked just okay. If the price made more sense in comparison to any other pho spot in town then great, filler me up, but it pales when you can get so much better for less. My advise, learn good pho and eat good pho, don't settle if you have the option.
author: Richard T.

description:
My first time here as I was looking for a place to grab lunch. I wanted something soup-y and remembered walking past this place once. It's your standard Vietnamese restaurant with a mix of brunch/diner cafe. They have other things on their menu such as salads. 

You order at the counter and then you can grab your number and sit down at a table. Water is self-serve as well. I was a little confused when I first walked in since I saw a bunch of tables but no one really came to seat me. I ordered #15 (vermicelli with pork and imperial roll) and it's $8 min for credit card (Visa/Mastercard). The food came quickly. I liked the vermicelli noodles and the pork and egg rolls were fine too. There were about 5-6 pieces of pork and the two rolls were cut up to a total of six bite-sized pieces. Foodwise, I would give it a 3 stars. I would have to try their other dishes to see how their pho holds up. But + extra star just because the man at the counter was friendly and had a smile on his face and made me feel welcome. A pleasant eating environment and the place is quite spacious. I think there are extra tables in the back once you go up the steps.
author: Diana C.

description: Ummm... $10 for subpar pho? Pass. If their meat was a little higher quality, you can justify it but nope. Their broth is pretty much beef stock from a can. My god wtf....why am I even reviewing this place????? Gdgajwusjndienieej28eudnnd ejeneje. Ejejb. 72heje8nsbiwhwjeiebe8en
author: Kai H.

description:
While the food may not always look visually appealing, and the menu has some of the expected typos, this place is truly a great family-run restaurant in SoMa.

It focuses on Vietnamese dishes, with a sprinkling of southern Chinese fare, and of course, breakfast sandwiches and coffee. Really not bad if you want some choices for a quick meal. I've not had any of their pho, because I'm sofa king over the pho phase, but this place offers decent vermicelli dishes with pretty good cha gio. I pretty much eat vermicelli every week, so this place is just another happy notch on my vermicelli hunt (just make sure to leave out the bean sprouts!). 

Their rice dishes are pretty relish too, but where I think this place really exceeds expectations is the service. The older man that always takes your order behind the counter is so friendly and polite. He reminds me of my parents' generation and their struggles for a better life trough education and hard work. Seriously, I want to give him a hug. The other workers are also constantly working. The last time I came around two pm and there were only two or three other parties, so when they could have had some down time I saw them clean their grill, disinfect their countertops, replenish condiments and utensils, etc.

Would totally come back here for the food and the service. It's a nice little inconspicuous gem.
author: Jamie C.

description:
I'm a first time regular, meaning I hold this place to a high esteem that I will come back  - real pho, family restaurant, close proximity to where I work, live and play. 

Restaurant is neat, even the bathroom which is a good indication. The sauces and napkins were full. 

Very generous with meat for pho combo. I enjoyed every bite.
author: Joba B.

description: Probably the best pho I've tried in the city! Huge fan of their broth as its super flavorful (also super salty, but that's part of the territory). This place is definitely quirky with its combo of an American diner menu and the classic Vietnamese choices, but this place is great! Love coming here for lunch.
author: Quinn Li O.

description: Got the rare steak pho. Extremely good, it looks a little dirty but the pho was great.
author: Kyle L.

description:
This is the yummiest little gem hidden in the middle of a very busy area. 

I came here spontaneously with my boyfriend for some pho and got a plain pho noodle, shrimp roll, and a bbq chicken sandwich and I was blown away. The servers were extremely friendly and quick and served us delicious food. The food was absolutely perfectly cooked and I was very impressed.

Definitely will be returning if I am around the area and 1000% recommend this place!! 

Help out small local restaurants and don't eat fast food!!
author: Rene L.

description:
This place gets a little crazy during lunch but has awesome bahn mis for a great price. Their pho is also really good. 

FYI there is an $8 minimum for cards.
author: Rebecca W.

description:
Sunrise has a mixed menu of standard American Deli/Diner along with Vietnamese dishes like pho, hu tieu, bun, and rice plates.

I got the #30, Pho Dac Biet (rare steak, brisket, flank, tendon, tripe, & beef balls, $7.75) with the rare steak on the side (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sunrise-cafe-san-francisco-2?select=qo1lsZVd4MT8H0rrC8Q3lw#qo1lsZVd4MT8H0rrC8Q3lw).

First thing I noticed was the really nice broth. It was slightly oily and had a good beefy flavor along with other spices. The meats were plentiful, flavorful and tender.  Minor ding for slightly overcooked noodles.  

While the pho are "typically priced" at $7-8, the banh mi are in the $4-5 range. I got a Banh Mi Thit Nuong (grilled pork, $4.50) to-go to see what you get for almost double what you can find at places like Saigon Sandwich.

This was not your usual crispy toasted baguette, but other than that things looked on the up & up with the meat, pickled diakon and carrots, slices of cucumber and jalepeno, and a smear of mayo (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sunrise-cafe-san-francisco-2?select=N2CWJNOgGJditNujmKrEzw#N2CWJNOgGJditNujmKrEzw)

There was plenty of tender, lean pork and mostly carrots. Definitely more fillings than your typical $2.50 banh mi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sunrise-cafe-san-francisco-2?select=N2CWJNOgGJditNujmKrEzw#Pf-ubggBFwIi-fxJMRNuhA). The roll wasn't doing it for me. It was dense and chewy and got in the way of my banh mi enjoyment. I thought would make a great casing for a cheesesteak (which they also have on the menu). 

Pho: 4+ stars
Banh mi: 3.5 stars
author: Andrew C.

description: Two doors away from my work.  So it's super convenient to call ahead and walk in.  I pretty much stick to the sandwiches since they're so good!  Go for the pork Vietnamese sandwich, that's my fave!  Will I be back?  For sure!
author: Jim P.

description:
Stopped by for lunch with coworkers. This place is a pretty standard run of the mill Vietnamese spot. Nothing is really stellar, but everything pretty much hits the spot. 

They also serve burgers and fries, which I have yet to try, but apparently are really good. So if you're looking for pho, banh mi, or a burger and fries, this place could hit the spot. 

One thing that I do like about the place in particular is their thai iced tea because it's not too sweet and is the perfect combination of caffeine and sugar to get me through the day at work.
author: Annie S.

description: For excellent traditional American/Vietnamese food you can't go wrong here. The Cha Gio (fried spring roll) are properly bubbly and crunchy on the outside, the Pho stock is homemade, and BBQ pork is deliciously seared and a little crispy on the edges in whatever dish you order it in. Good strong iced Vietnamese coffee. And the husband/wife owner team couldn't be nicer! Highly recommended.
author: Daniel K.

description: You'll always find a seat, large extra room in the back. The banh mi is so-so but good enough to fill that craving. Solid noodle and rice dishes, just your average hole in the wall that delivers. Steady and not special.
author: Gonzalo S.

description: This place has really good pho soup and that is usually what I look for first in a pho restaurant. Price is pretty average and it is interesting that they also serve things like burgers and sandwiches. The only thing that bothered me was how their noodles were way too soft and I couldn't feel what I was chewing on.
author: Andy A.

description:
Total dive place which I normally like.  We ordered at 1pm when it wasn't too crowded, but had to wait 27 minutes  to get ours after asking twice (although people who came after us got their food faster in 10 minutes).

Food was fine.

Prices were the same as places that are cleaner and better food.  Service was bad.  Not going back.
author: Java Z.

description:
This place is a true hidden gem! Walking past and into the restaurant, you wouldn't expect it to be a good food spot, but let me tell you - there are so many options on their menu and the food is DELICIOUS. 

Every time I come, I get the combination pho, bbq pork banh mi and an iced coffee. Every time I come here, it hits the spot. The portions are big and you could easily share your food between 2 people. Additionally, the owners are super nice and they make it feel like you're getting home cooked meals. 

Don't let looks deceive you and come check this place out!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
This place seemed a bit sketchy from the outside, but walking inside revealed a pretty large space with two separate seating areas. Their menu is somewhat confusing though; they seemed to have American items on one wall, pictures of more Asian things on another wall, and a somewhat more complete menu for you to pick up and look as well. Strange combinations really, as they seemed to have common Chinese, Thai, and Vietnamese dishes all at once.

Based on other reviews, I went for the pork banh mi, and it wasn't a bad choice at all. While a bit small, it was still very filling and the pork was delicious. It came with just the right amount of filling like carrots, cilantro, and a slice of cucumber and jalapeno. Not a bad choice if you're in the area.
author: Tony D.

description:
We normally go tO Them Ki in the Tenderloin but I saw all the great reviews and figured we would give Sunrise a try. 

Not impressed. 

The Bahn me was half as good as Saigon Sandwich and cost a lot more ($6).

I got Garlic noodle & BBQ Chicken. It was eh. 80% noodle, 10% chicken & 10% Veggies. And again a higher price than you find in Little Saigon.

Chicken Pho was sparse on the chicken for $9.20 inc tax.

Well we gave it a try.
author: Robert H.

description:
This place (for me) on  saturday afternoon is chill and easy going. I was looking for decently priced food since SF can be SO expensive. 

I ordered vermicelli with chicken and egg rolls. I normally don't admire eggrolls too much but these eggrolls are unique and delicious! Food was quick and the people there are friendly. for a $8-9 meal, i'm generally pleased. It has many  options and is a great post-Costco meal
author: Katrina N.

description: The Pho was good.  Broth not spectacular, but decent.  Tendon OK and rare beef delicious. Plenty of bean sprouts and peppers etc.  Noodles good quality. Inexpensive.
author: Ronnie W.

description: I was really rooting for this place. I wanted the divey exterior and interior to not matter. I wanted the food to taste authentic and amazing. It was just okay. The server who I'm assuming was also the owner was super nice, though. I would happily go again for that reason alone. And the food is not bad either, I was just hoping for it to be another hidden gem uncovered by Yelp and it wasn't.
author: Dean I.

description: Came here on a Saturday and it was relatively quiet. Was excited to see they had Vietnamese sandwiches on the menu, so we stayed even though we were short on time. Glad we did. We ordered a beef BBQ, pork BBQ, and pate sandwiches to share. We also ordered shrimp rolls for an appetizer. It was all absolutely delicious, and everything was like 20 bucks. Would come again.
author: Diana G.

description: BBQ chicken sandwich and tofu vegetable sandwich are ridiculously good! 2 sandwiches, shrimp springroll and 2 ice coffees for less than $21! Please keep it a secret yelp, just between u and I! ;)
author: Florence F.

description:
Formally known as Sunrise Cafe. 

3/5 stars only because it's a bit more expensive then most Vietnamese places, food is decent. Nothing mind blowing overall.

Recommend:
Deep fried imperial rolls
Bun Bo Hue
Bun Riêu
author: Denny L.

description:
Don't let my three stars fool you, in general I actually really do like this establishment. Coworkers and I walked by it one day and decided to give it a shot the next day since people were craving pho. What really stands out to me about this place is how homey the cooking is. The decor is certainly subpar, but everything is freshly cooked and when the guy who owns the places gives it to you, you feel like you're at home and you've just had a parent cook for you.

I got rice noodles and friends around me had pho, the rice wraps, etc. Overall just solid Vietnamese food in general. Nothing too great, but nothing terrible either. Prices run relatively low which is pretty nice. 

I definitely suggest anything with their broth--their stock broth was spectacular. Really haven't tasted anything quite like it in awhile. 

tldr; good place if you're craving cheap viet food in the area
author: Jasmine X.

description: Food is good and cheap, have eaten 150-200 of their bbq chicken sandwich over the years. The service during the lunch rush can be quite terrible. Expect to wait 30-45 minutes for a sandwich. Food 4.5 stars, service 3 stars.
author: Chris B.

description: Sunrise cafe, the homey, dive that sells everything adequately but made more delicious by the comforting feeling this place and people give out the more often you come here.  They do sell everything from US diner food to Vietnamese diner food to espresso based drinks.  The iced coffee is my staple.
author: Susana S.

description: Went here for some Pho since we were shopping at Costco.  Pho is hard to rate because it usually tastes the same at all restaurants.  The price is average for SF, and the portion is the same as other Pho restaurants.  Compared to the Tenderloins, it is a little pricier but that is the same for any restaurant.  The owner or worker was very nice.  Would go back if I'm ever in the need of Pho.
author: Justin Y.

description:
Really good family owned hole-in-the-wall spot that's actually pretty spacious with a back room inside.

The bf introduced me to this place after one of his friend's brought him a banh mi sandwich from here and he was instantly hooked! You can't go wrong!

Whenever we're here, he always gets a pork banh mi and I get the chicken one. He loves the pork one and I'm always satisfied with the chicken one! The owner explained that they really grill their meat unlike other places where they just deep-fry it. 

On another occasion, I tried their pho ga and was pleasantly surprised that it contained all white meat. It was also my first time having it with wide noodles and it was pretty good. 

Check this place out if you're in the area and support your local mom-and-pop business! Affordable good food with friendly service!
author: Fallon P.

description:
I had no idea there was legit Vietnamese food so close to my work until today!  I always say that if a restaurant gets their Bun Thit Nuong (BBQ pork over vermicelli) right, then they're legit--especially when they make their Cha Gio (fried eggrolls) with rice wrap instead of egg wonton wrap.  I got the Thai Iced Tea and it was made perfectly as well.  Will definitely be back to try the Pho and Banh Mi.  

We got to the restaurant around 11:30 AM to skip the crowd and the place was almost empty.  Within 20 minutes, people began to file in.  By the time it was noon, the line was literally out the door.  For now, Sunrise Cafe has my vote for the best affordable Vietnamese food in the SOMA.  They take your order before you can sit down so grab a couple of friends and have them save a spot while you order.
author: Ivy Z.

description: I got the project chop and shedded pork Vietnamese platter. It was delicious. They also have American, Chinese and Thai food. Pretty busy at noon but found a seat. The took a little bit if time to arrive but well worth the wait.
author: Jonas K.

description: I love this place the pork chops are so good. I like the cashier Michael he is always so friendly. I'm definitely coming back.....
author: Sandra A.

description:
Their banh mi's are also delicious and you can make it as crazy as you want. Chicken and pork? Sure. Pâté? Sure. Eggs overeasy, overwell, overhard, over-however you like? Sure! The guy who usually works the register always welcomes interesting combinations.

I tried their rice plates today too and it hit the spot. BBQ pork, crispy egg rolls, and egg over rice. All for $9.
author: Rosie W.

description:
GREAT BBQ chicken bánh mì! I have had a lot of bành mì and this is definitely one of my favorites thus far. There's a lot of meat on the sandwich and of course it's a great price.

The staff is very friendly. The restaurant has tons of seating, so if you come during lunch rush there will probably be somewhere to sit.

Come try it!
author: Elizabeth V.

description: Sunrise Cafe is a good place for Pho in the South of Market area.  They have a variety of Vietnamese dishes as well as American staples such as breakfast fare egg dishes and burger and fries.  When I am in the craving for Pho, I make the 2-block trek from my place of employment to enjoy the combo Pho, which does not disappoint! Tender slices of beef, meatballs and tasty broth. You can also have all the tea you can drink, included with your meal.  Not the greatest Pho I've ever tasted, but it surely beats its competitor, Grab 'N Go! I've only sampled the Combo Pho, but they have others, like a Chicken Pho and one with a tomato-based broth.
author: Steven L.

description: soma grease spoon...standard american burger, sandwich, salad and soup servings $5 to $6...random solo teriyaki chicken plate $7.50...cafe with coffee drinks under $2 to $3...talk about a smorgasbord menu option...and, standard vietnamese pho restaurant...springs rolls, egg rolls, bbq plates, bun bo hue, pho ga, etc...stopping by for a lunch on the road...quick alley parking and lucky finding a single spot....banh mi ready-made, wrapped and rubber banded piled along stove top edge $5.15...pricey and small, but filled quite heavy...breading quite the crunchy outer...cilantro, julienned carrots and bbq meat loaded...cut in half and two baseball sized portions...good, but destroying mouth on hard crust...
author: Hen A.

description: $10 for a bowl of pho? That's a bit much for pho that's alright. The good thing is this place is open even during most holidays and the Vietnamese coffee was strong and good too.
author: Gerard Y.

description: This is your typical "hole in the wall" place which looks close to nothing from the outside but should you miss it, you're out of luck! I'm Indian but I love a good bowl of Pho as much as my Biryani, and I must say, this place has one of the BEST pho I've ever had in San Francisco. I've tried a bunch of their pho dishes, but #39 is my favorite! Gets super crowded for lunch (for obvious reasons!), but the service is fast and worth every penny. Can't speak much for the other items on their menu, but I'm sure they're just as good. And the owner is so warm and welcoming!
author: Anu R.

description: Great banh mi with crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside French bread.
author: Brandon L.

description: Always tried something new here and it always approved my taste buds.  Even thou it gets really busy here sometimes on lunch, it is still quick and efficient.
author: Jenn C.

description: If you're looking for celebrities here -- good luck. If you're looking for above average food -- even more good luck.
author: Curt Q.

description: Love this little slice of heaven.  Perfect place for a rainy day.  You can't go wrong with anything on the menu!
author: Jen M.

description: a block and a half from my job, I call in and it's always ready when I get there. Fresh ingredients make a huge difference, and they know that. Always impressed with every meal.
author: Brian P.

description:
Banh Mi is Delicious (~$5). My favorite is the Pate and Cha Lua (Vietnamese lunch meat). A $5 sandwich that packs a punch that'll leave you filling nice and full. They don't skimp you on meat, veggies or pate. 

They have other dishes: Pho, Rice, Noodles. ~$10. What was appreciated was a huge menu complete with pictures! You order at the counter and sit in. They accept credit cards with a minimum charge.

The restaurant looks a bit outdated, but the food was good and that made the old restaurant that hadn't been remodeled since the 1960's okay. Despite being old, the restaurant felt clean enough. 

STREET PARKING ONLY. You may have better luck in alley beside the restaurant.
author: Christine B.

description:
Sunrise Cafe is right around the corner from my office and I'm not embarrassed (okay, maybe a little!) to admit that I eat here 2-3 times per week. With so many yummy options at great prices for even my vegetarian tastes, it's hard to go anywhere else! I often take my food to go but there is hot tea that's yummy if you eat in. Here are my go-to dishes, these are all veggie options:

- bun with tofu and veggie spring rolls - the way they prepare their tofu is so good; I'm not sure how they do it but I love it!
- vietnamese tofu sandwich, add avocado - the tofu is back in this dish and the jalapeno spice is just right!
- veggie pho - I'm not a strict vegetarian so I've never actually asked if the broth has any chicken in it... lots of yummy vegetables though!
- deluxe salad - not really an Asian dish except I ask for the bun sauce to use as dressing - for less than $6 includes avocado, egg, chickpeas, and much more plus bread on the side

The people that work at Sunrise Cafe are also so nice and they always make me happy when I go to order my Sunrise lunch!
author: Meghan P.

description:
Banh mi is great. I always get the bbq pork. Pho is fine.

If you're lucky, the man who takes your order will say "Happy Birthday" instead of "Have a nice day." He's very sweet.
author: Denise I.

description: If you are looking for quick sandwich you can stop bye and get the good Vietnamese Sandwiches
author: Jay V.

description:
Cheap food.  Taste Great.  Great weekday lunch spot.

Seating feels like a cafeteria.

Banh Mi - Pretty good.
Vermecelli w/ pork and egg roll - Decent
author: Steven F.

description: My first time here and I ordered some pho Tai Sach. Good food and reasonable prices. Will likely be back.
author: M G.

description: The owner is very nice and makes you feel welcome.  The place isn't fancy but they have good food.  I am a fan of their Vietnamese sandwiches and pork chops with rice.
author: Paul A.

description:
The honey and I dropped in for some really tasty well priced udon and fabulous Italian sodas and were greeted with some great service during our visit.

There's a goodly amount of seating and the area isn't too bad. 

I'd come back.
author: Meg T.

description: The food was all right. I had the pineapple fried rice which was tasty, and my friends seemed to enjoy their pho and clay pot and stew. When I was there, there was really awful construction going on outside though, so it was super loud and didn't make for a pleasant dining experience. I hope to go back though and give it another chance. The staff was friendly, and the prices were inexpensive.
author: Bianca C.

description:
This is a pretty decent Vietnamese restaurant.  Great for lunch and easily identifiable food.  The menu is like any other similar restaurant so don't get discouraged.  Ask questions and find out the food item that fits best for you.

My personal favorite is the #17 which is BBQ chicken, egg rolls and vermicelli.  Good stuff.  And for $7.50 you can't beat the price.
author: Kevin J.

description: This place is awesome!  I was craving some curry pho and yelp helped me find this spot.  I noticed it before coming off the 9th Street exit but I'm glad I was able to finally try it.  The curry soup was delicious - hot with the perfect amount of protein and veggies.  I've tried the chicken pho which is also good but like the curry, the broth is a bit on the oily side.  The food is always nice and hot and food is made by the order.  The banh mi is good and only $5.  The place is a little divey and the prices are a little high.  But if the food is this good, venue and price is not an issue.  This place gets its share of traffic but you will always probably find a seat.  The staff is friendly.  There are a lot of choices on the menu.   They offer different dishes that include american, thai, vietnamese and korean.  Enjoy!
author: Chris S.

description: It's not on the menu, but they will make a mist deliciously amazing vegetarian noodle soup for you by request. So happy.
author: Lesley G.

description: Worst experience EVER! Not only is it a pain to find parking in this city but then I come here to eat food, wait 15 mins to order, 20 mins for the food to come out to only find out they got the order wrong. Not only did I have to PAY for another meal but they offer to make it right
author: Martin S.

description:
Tried this place out on a whim. It's incredibly well-priced. The ambiance is... let's say unassuming. I found it endearing. The service was wonderful-- our cashier/waiter was extremely cheerful and friendly. 

I almost ordered the beef combo (which includes tripe, tongue, and a variety of cow parts) because of the generic sounding name. Maybe I'll be brave enough to order that next time. Went with the shrimp pho for my cold, and it was delicious. I'll be back.
author: Hill A.

description:
Quick, cheap, and good. It's a nice combination to have.

Came in here for a quick lunch to go. The shop is alot bigger on the inside then it looks. Big menu which serves American and Vietnamese breakfasts and lunches with coffees and flavored drinks to boot. They also have a menu with pictures. :)

Ordered the chicken pho and a chicken Vietnamese sandwich ( in the mood for chicken ) with a drink. Price about ... $11 big portion.

My sandwich was warm, flavorful, crispy, and just the right amount of spice. The veggies were fresh and complimented the BBQ chicken nicely. Great warm sauce added.

The pho was perfect. Noodles were fresh broth was perfect and clear. So good. Now I'm just hungry for some more again. I will definitely be back.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Can't beat the prices here! The pork banh mi sandwiches are the best I've found in SF. It's a small hole in the wall spot that's easy to miss, but once you get inside it's super homey, clean, and has great service. Call in a sandwich for pick up, you won't be disappointed

~ TheWaterGuy
author: Daniel T.

description: I've been to this place a few times for lunch after I started working at a place less than a block away. I usually get the chicken Banh Mi which is always really good, but a little more expensive than what I am used to paying for a very similar sandwich at other Vietnamese places ($6vs$3-4). They do seem to use better quality chicken here, but I don't think that really justifies it being almost double the price of most other places. Aside from the price, the food is good and service is quick. Would be the perfect lunch spot if their prices were $1-2 lower.
author: Hannah G.

description:
Friendly service from start to finish.

I ordered a large pho ga for takeout for $9 something and two tofu rolls for $5. It's the most expensive Vietnamese restaurant I've been to, but I guess you pay for convenience. The broth was delicious and the chicken was moist, with lots of chicken with skin and a decent amount of dark meat--Asian comfort food, indeed. (I'd be pretty disappointed if the skin was missing, and if they only used breast meat!) I asked for extra toppings (onions, cilantro, peppers, bean sprouts, limes, basil etc.) and got it all but the extra lime. But, at least they included the premixed Sriracha and hoisin sauce without asking. I'll definitely emphasize on extra limes next time! 

Overall, good but pricier Vietnamese food. Comparable to Turtle Tower vs. other restaurants.

I'll be back, just not as often as I'd like.
author: jolie L.

description:
This place is consistently fast, fresh and good-tasting -never have complaints on the simple food. My only issues is that it is not the cleanest and if you sit in the back room the smell of the stinky bathrooms waft throughout. I recommend getting it for take out, or at least sit at the front-near the door if you can. 

Try the lemongrass beef. Sooo good!
author: nancy s.

description:
This review is for PHO only - dropped in here for lunch close to Costco & this was by far the WORST pho ive EVER had! 

Where to begin? Well the noodles werent even the traditional noodles served in most pho (no warning in advance) & the bits of 'beef' or whatever nasty looking bits that was served were just disgusting imo. The broth was oily & tasteless & overall this was a HORRID lunch for my experience... Btw I ordered the 'Spicy Beef Pho' & it was even OVERPRICED @ 8$. 

The style if this restaurant is more if a quick-and-go-away diner & the only food I'd even consider ordering again would be a grilled cheese sandwich with a side of sliced tomato & lettuce (NOT that I will ever go back!)
author: Julian I.

description:
Lately I've been trying more of the noodle dishes, and I still have yet to sample anything to my disliking.

The Chicken Pho (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rIMHcAS7IShUXXx38t6WKw?select=gURYXlGgcYAmKI48jvFUxQ) is very good.  Served in a medium sized bowl expect a mountain of soft rice vermicelli in a clear well-seasoned chicken broth.  Lots of boneless chicken meat (includes skin) and a healthy sprinkling of fresh green onion and cilantro are presented on top of the noodle bed.  A plate of fresh bean sprouts, jalapeno rings, fresh basil and a lemon wedge (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rIMHcAS7IShUXXx38t6WKw?select=-3vrFr3vza2om8FKEyMFvg) accompanies your pho.

The BBQ Shrimp / BBQ Pork Combo with Vermicelli (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rIMHcAS7IShUXXx38t6WKw?select=w67-H0bQpgrj5oTTT44zSA) is amazing.  Soft, chewy, cold vermicelli sits on top of a bed of shredded lettuce,cucumber and mint and topped with pork and shrimp garnished with green onions and crushed peanuts.  Shreds of  pickled carrot and daikon are presented to the side.  The different flavors combined together for a surprising taste sensation.  A similar dish is the BBQ Chicken with Egg Roll and Vermicelli (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rIMHcAS7IShUXXx38t6WKw?select=weAAidkTf5W3ERaZZ86BjA).

You can also order a Hamburger with Fries (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rIMHcAS7IShUXXx38t6WKw?select=XwwtxPDyv_pmRiR1KS-K_A).  Cheese and avocado can be added at an additional cost, but the base burger is less than $5.  Not very juicy, but the half pound burger is moist.  It comes with lettuce, tomato, red onion and pickles with only mayonnaise on the bun.  The fries are generic.  Overall, it's an average burger so I would stick with the Vietnamese food.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Review for pho ONLY.

Pho noodles were gummy. Meager portions of meat. Broth was good.

Leaving 2 stars for the pho but will be back to try the Bunh Mi. Service was fine, place was decently clean.
author: Moids M.

description:
The Vietnamese sandwiches, Bahn Mi's, are *amazing*. Quick and affordable I've tasted the pork + chicken, but I'm a fan of the tofu.

I've had the chicken pho several times and perhaps it's just me and my vegetarian tendencies, but their was a lot of skin on the chicken pieces. I guess that's one of those good problems if you're an avid meat-eater. For me, I found it hard to digest. The broth was delicious, and, considering I was fighting a flu at the time, was exactly what I needed.
author: Sprout S.

description:
The owner pretty much memorized my order each time I eat there since I eat there quite often during lunch and I always order the same thing: tofu vietnamese sandwich with overhard egg. MmMmMm! Add a lot of sriracha all over and I'm in heaven each time. Can't just eat half the sandwich because it's too delicious. My coworkers have ordered the curry chicken noodle soup, pho, rice places, breakfast plates, but I've always stuck to the tofu banh mi since I'm a pescatarian. I think I ordered sugarcane shrimp ball vermicelli noodles once which wasn't that memorable. 

Restaurant has tons of seating, food is delivered to your table, and you don't need to clean up after yourselves!

TRY THE BANH MIs!
author: Jackie L.

description: Love that this is a place where you order at the counter and sit down wherever you want. Food was solid, reasonably priced and quick. My only disappointment was that there wasn't enough shrimp in my noodles.
author: Shannon B.

description:
It's been a while since I've had pho that actually tasted like it was made from scratch. While not the big beefy flavor you've come to know, you could actually pick out the subtle nuances in the broth, a hint of clove, the light handed fish sauce, etc.

For $7.75, the dac biet bowl was tasty and satisfying, good amount of well cooked beef and noodles. 

They also have banh mi and from the large menu, I also spotted hainan chicken, which I might try next time.

I'll be back to this humble mom and pop for sure.
author: Derrick V.

description:
The usual pho #1 is #30 here.
My noodles were all broken :[
Pretty pricey for the amount of meat/meatballs I got
The server's nails were longer and yellower than I can usually handle
Service was nice :]
author: kim w.

description:
Since I work not too far from here, this place has become a staple in my lunch routine. Breakfast sandwiches have become a delicious new discovery (with bacon on a croissant please) especially if you had a bit too much sauce the night before.

Other good finds involve the clay pot, pho ga, giant salads served in bowls my grandma happens to own and they even have a pretty decent cheeseburger. Oh, and crinkly fries, yum.

Only drawback happens to be the feeling that everything is slightly overpriced, but definitely not enough to stop me from nomming here.
author: Andrew  M.

description:
My office is located just a block or so from Sunrise, and I go there for lunch with my coworkers 2-4 times a week. I've tried a ton of things on the menu, and can say I've never been disappointed.

Whether it's the spicy beef noodle soup, the chicken pho, the lemongrass chicken with string beans and rice or the clay pot, everything is delicious. Oh and the fries ROCK!

The staff is sooooo nice and friendly - there's a reason we keep coming back day after day!
author: Nicole H.

description: Mmm tasty early morning pho and crispy egg roll....3.5 stars - not the best i've ever had, but still totes delish! Visited in 2011.
author: Caitlin S.

description: There is good, functional Vietnamese food here. I've never understood people's craze over Banh mi, but I can vouch that everything else here tastes good. The pho isn't godly, but you'd be hard-pressed to find better at a similar price in Soma.
author: Nathan Y.

description: Very simple and humble place with amazing chicken pho and chicken Viet sandwich! If you need a caffeine kick , try their Viet coffee!
author: Guillermo S.

description:
Stopped in here the other day on a chilly Saturday afternoon. I was planning to go grab a taco elsewhere but the lingering smell of garlic and spices wafting out of their doors drew me in. It smelled THAT good.

Sunrise Cafe like most places in the Mission is an unassuming, simple place that resembles a takeout joint. So don't expect much in terms of service or decor. 

But when it comes to the food you really can't go wrong with the lunch special ($8.95) for a bowl of hot and sour soup, an imperial roll, a salad, an entree, and rice - and huge portions at that. Seriously, I was beyond full and had a full lunch for the next day. Being a bit of a health nut I was really happy to see the amount of veggie dishes on the menu and that brown rice was available. 

Like I said, you really can't go wrong with the food here. They have huge portions and affordable prices. I'll be making my way back here soon, if only for a bowl of noodle soup which everyone else seemed to be ordering.
author: Priscilla M.

description: This is a no-frills good eats Vietnamese cafe with friendly Ma & Pop service and charm.
author: Didie P.

description:
Just went to Sunrise Cafe for the first time with my co-workers. We each ordered a different dish so that we could share and try out several of the menu items. I am giving this cafe one star because there was a ROCK in the egg rolls. We thought it was a whole peppercorn at first, but it was, in fact, a rock. Disgusting.

Overall, the food was just okay. The meat was really dry in every dish. The portions were small, causing the dishes to be way overpriced. We ordered:

          #15 - BBQ Pork & Egg Roll w/Vermicelli ($7.50)
          #30 - Combo Beef Noodle Soup ($7.75)
          #37 - Rare Steak, Tripe Noodle Soup ($6.95)
          #52 - BBQ Beef w/Rice ($6.50)

We all agreed that there are much better restaurants in the area and that we would not be coming back to this cafe. In addition, they are charging 9.1% sales tax even though the sales tax rate in San Francisco is 8.5%.

However, I will say that this place seems like it is very popular. The line to order was consistently out the door throughout the lunch hour. The service is fast, and it looks like they have some banh mi pre-made and ready to go.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Great prices and food.

The family who owns the cafe are really friendly and welcoming. I always order the com dia (rice plate) with chicken and imperial rolls. Good portion and very filling. The service is quick and there is plenty of space in the dining room with an additional room in the back which is for the lunch crowd I'm assuming. 

They offer not only vietnamese food but also American cafe food such as sandwiches, breakfast plates and coffee.
author: Fran N.

description: My go-to spot for banh mi and Vietnamese coffee during lunch breaks.
author: Suzi G.

description: Crazy during lunch hours. There's usually a long line when I come here so I always call in my order. The staff are friendly. There's a lot of seating for people who want to sit down and eat.  The banh mi here is cheap & great ! I have yet to try their pho, but it looks tasty from what I see.
author: Sara L.

description: For an inexpensive and overall solid Asian spot... this is the place to go.  Nothing about this place screams high quality... but the food isn't bad.  There is food options from all over Asia here, but I tend to stick to the clay pot special.
author: Andrew S.

description: Quick, delicious, and cheap. There is nothing fancy about this joint but the old man behind the counter is incredibly nice, food comes out super quick, and portions are good.
author: Melinda C.

description: Solid bun. Fish sauce is excellent and plentiful, and the pork isn't gristly.  My colleague who is Vietnamese said the food was excellent, and they have a crab soup that is pretty traditional and not easy to find.
author: Jen L.

description: Pork bahn-mi was really good!  Crisp bread, not stale at all.   Garlic noodles were a flop -seemed kind of like frozen vegetables mixed in and not very flavorful.
author: Laura Z.

description:
4 stars in terms of Vietnamese cuisine in SF. (It'd be 3 if it were SJ...)

Great place to have a quick lunch if you work in the area or happen to be in the area. They offer a large variety of vietnamese dishes, along with some american items (burgers, fries...). I saw the bo kho (beef stew) noodles and immediately knew I had to get a banh mi bo kho, which is just the stew with no noodles and a loaf of bread on the side for dipping. The flavors were pretty good, great on a cold day. I just wish they didn't give me so much cartilage and fat on the beef. There were pieces of carrot and onions as they should be.

Co-workers got bun rieu (crab paste tomato soup with tofu), which looked pretty good and the others got bun thit nuong cha gio (vermicelli noodles with grilled pork and egg rolls). Everyone enjoyed their meal and everything was decently priced. Next time I want to try the bun rieu and pho with fresh/large noodles.

Lots and I mean lots of space in here. It's huge. No wait, there were some other patrons in here eating lunch also so it's not a ghost town or anything. The chicken banh mi also looks popular here.
author: Stine H.

description:
Was all fired up for Tu Lan, my favorite Vietnamese place when I lived here.  My friend wasn't too keen to park his coche on 6th and Mission (don't know why) so went here instead.  A big surprise!

I had the Bun w/Pork and Imperial Roll (which I always get at V-places) and it was the real deal.  Rolls were double fried just like Tu Lan.   Not quite as good but my #1 pet peeve are Vietnamese places that sell Chinese egg rolls and call them Imperial rolls.   The pork was great, succulent and nicely charred just like Jefe likes it.  Add vermicelli noodles, fresh greens, and fish sauce, and we're in heaven.

I ordered a Chicken Bahn Mi (Vietnamese sandwich) as an appetizer and that was the superstar of the meal.  Great bread and really tasty BBQd chicken...big enough to be its own meal.   Can't miss.

Based on the reviews I've read, come here for the Vietnamese food (duh) vs. the  breakfast or faux american like Philly Cheesteaks.
author: Geoff C.

description: Probably the nearest Vietnamese restaurant to Townsend. I like their Thai Ice Tea because Vietnam and Thailand are the same thing right :P.
author: Thomas C.

description: Awesome vietnamese food!  Great bahn mi's and buns!
author: mark h.

description: This place is sort of like an american diner welded into a vietnamese eatery. I got the banh mi ga nuong to go. Lots of chicken, good amount of the pickled veggies, crispy roll but not overly crispy. Good, fast and efficient service when the banh mi was served. Mid-range price for the sandwich. They also have serve pho and other great Viet dishes as well. Overall good experience.
author: Derek N.

description:
Neighborhood special.

I live half a block from Sunrise cafe. Ever since I moved to my apt, my boyfriend and I've been a regular here. 

As it turned out this place not only serves American Breakfast but also Vietnamese food, we were very happy. (my boyfriend is Vietnamese- American) They get fresh pastries every morning too :)

They make pretty good Vietnamese coffee and pho ga (those are my staples here), as well as pho combo and some other noodle dishes. As a bowl of pho, it's tidbit expensive than standard pricing around here. But over all, considering how close it is to my house, it's just unbeatable. 

Yes, I will go back there again, and again. Yay for pho in 30 sec walking range!!
author: Mayumi Y.

description: I enjoyed my visit here.  When places are closed on holidays (so many restaurants were closed in SF on Thanksgiving weekend), you can always count on the Asian restaurants being open.  My bf had the pork banh mi (Vietnamese sandwich) and it was good. It was about 6 inches long (I think he was expecting more but it was satisfying).  I copied off others in the restaurant and got the pork over vermicelli and egg rolls. I enjoyed my meal. The thai iced tea was off and left a bit of a weird after taste. The pho or soup like dishes at the other table looked good.
author: Jessica S.

description: Seemingly in the middle of nowhere.  If you happen to be shopping at Nordstrom Rack, Samy's or 9th and Bryant, this is a tasty place to refresh yourself. Just a minute walk down Bryant.  Came for the banh mi sandwiches and were not disappointed.  Phoa was good and the French coffee was authentic.  Service was friendly and personable.
author: Marc L.

description:
I've lived on Dore Street for about a year now, and have frequented this cafe many times with my girlfriend.

We almost exclusively order Vietnamese menu items, with the one time exception when I ordered their Chef Salad... which resulted in a giant bowl with all the fixings.

NEVER THE LESS!

Pho Ga is not bad... its pretty decent considering I just open my door and walk down the street half a block... really good when I had a long night out and just need to do some soul searching over a nice hot bowl of chicken soup.

Bun Bo Hue is not bad as well. You can't beat your own mother's soup, so she takes the cake with all noodles. But back to the plan at hand... their soup is good... ingredients here and there some authentic, some borrowed from their Pho Tai... whatever, I eat it because its close and its pretty good...

Their rice plates are a little lackluster... Com Suong Bi Cha is pretty good... but the portions... man the portions...

All in all this is a great spot that we frequent quite often for quick bites before we head off, or morning num nums.

We have met the couple who owns this restaurant at Manila Market quite a few times and exchange hellos and goodbyes quite often. It feels good to have a nice corner spot with nice people, its refreshing in this city, and more so in SOMA.
author: Christopher L.

description: This is definitely more of a grab-and-go restaurant/cafe atmosphere but don't let it fool you! The guy working was so nice, the prices are super reasonable, and the food came out super fast! My friend and I shared a bunch of stuff. I've never had a bun mi before and I thought it was good but the Pho was amazing. So spicy and flavorful - I got the spicy beef pho.
author: chloe d.

description:
One of the few Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood besides Grab n Go or the new Turtle Restaurant.  I ordered the Pork banh mi and an order of imperial rolls (aka egg rolls) to go.

The whole banh mi taste just wasn't there.  I think they were missing the mayonaise.  They didn't even have dikons in it!  I think they use a deli roll instead of a Vietnamese baguette.  It was toasty, but a little too toasty where it was almost impossible to bite through.
author: H. L.

description:
Under assuming place tucked close by to costco. Don't expect too much from it. Looks wise, it's very dingy and not well cleaned like the very old cafe it is. Vietnamese American food it is, though the only thing closest to American I ordered there was the depth charge coffee. 

Food ordered:

1) shrimp roll. Not made fresh to order, saw the guy pull it off the rest to go previously packaged area. But the BBQ pork in it made the difference in taste and different from most spring rolls. Coupled with the fish sauce made it super delicious!

2) pork banh mi: stuffed with all fresh ingredients ( pickled carrots, cilantro, pork, jalapeños). Also very delicious, though it would've been made better if there was some pate in it. 

3) depth charge coffee (expresso + regular coffee. Nothing much to report here. Just slightly stronger than any old coffee.

4) bun rieu & pho combo. I lump summed these two under pho/noodle soup cause these two were a little underwhelming. Not too much flavor, noodle and beef in broth. Don't come here for these.
author: Kevy C.

description: sort of disappointing pho ga. It really just tasted sort of bland. My cha gio were solid though. I'd go back and definitely order something else because I think they know what they're doing
author: Misha T.

description: This review is for their 2 egg and cheddar cheese breakfast sandwich on a French roll. Egg is fine, cheese was American, bread was a hot dog bun. For $5, probably one of the most disappointing breakfast sandwiches ever bought from a Vietnamese place that serves banh mi.  Why is it not even on a French roll??  You cheaped out in the worst way, Sunrise. Fail.
author: Nth S.

description: Ordered 2 pork banh mi sandwiches to go.  They were decent, but nothing special.
author: B. Y.

description: Are you hungover, stuck in SOMA, craving pho tai, and not wanting to settle for Turtle Tower's watered down pho ga? If so, come here. You will not be let down!
author: Jerome C.

description:
Banh mi panorama is absolutely intriguing and it's amazing how few ingredients can result in so many little differences.
Sunrise cafe' does a good job, veggies were fresh and crunchy, mayo looks like being homemade BUT meat (bbq pork) and bread are pedestrian, especially at $4.65.
Good, don't get me wrong, but not enough to be a winner.
author: Dario B.

description: The sign boasts American and Vietnamese food, so I didn't expect much going in. I was highly surprised! It did not and has not disappointed! The food is really good. The broth of the Pho tastes great. Haven't tried the Banh Mi yet. To be continued...
author: Helen L.

description:
Yum, yum, YUM!

This is one of my most favorite restaurants in the whole city. The prices are more then reasonable and they have delicious pho. The atmosphere is low key and friendly, the owner always has a smile on. They have a pretty big menu and nothing I've had there  has disappointed me.

Another plus for me, they carry my favorite coconut juice with pulp, Parrot.
author: Sarah G.

description: I have lunch here about 3 times a week. Everything I try on the menu has been excellent. The sandwiches are tasty and affordable. The Pho is excellent and the staff is friendly.
author: Jesse P.

description:
The pho and beef stew are decent. One more star for the cheap price.

Also, i think this is the only pho restaurant where you can get a bowl of pho and a cheeseburger on the side (with fries).
author: Albert C.

description:
One of the top vietnamese restaurants in the city--seriously. Some of the best pho around and killer salad rolls and vietnamese sandwiches. For the money you can't beat it. Used to be the korso cafe. They kept that part of the business going and still sell great coffee at great prices. Hell, where in the city can you get a great tasting latte or cappuccino for $2.65?!? 

Check them out first for Vietnamese food and second for their coffee. You won't be disappointed.
author: Eric D.

description:
Chef salad with vietnamese BBQ (tofu, beef, and chicken)  are A+++.
Vietnamese noodle taste good, broth is prefect taste.
author: SteveMorris M.

description:
I love their Vietnamese sandwiches! I visited this spot with my boyfriend and shared a chicken sandwich and a beef sandwich. Delicious!! Both were so good that we couldn't pick which we liked more. I didn't try any of the other food, so I can't say if they were good or not, but I definitely recommended visiting this place for their sandwiches. I think they marinate and bbq their meat well, which makes the sandwiches really flavorful.

The restaurant itself isn't anything impressive, though. So don't go here expecting nice decorations and top of the line furniture. It's somewhat like a hole in the wall. If you don't mind just having the basics and focusing more on the food alone, then this is a great place to visit.
author: Robin I.

description: Pretty solid all the way around.  Decent food, quick service.
author: Adam M.

description: What they lack in decor, the make up for in great tasting food! They have a mixed menu, with lots of choices. We had the Pho, spring rolls, and pork & tofu hotpot.  We will definitely come back here.
author: Wendy R.

description: Went for lunch and got the seafood pho. Staff was really nice, and food came out fast. Pretty standard pho, but definitely good. Prices were a little higher than average. Would recommend if you're already in the area and hungry.
author: Denise R.

description: No frills hole in the wall that looks shady on the outside, but very clean inside. The pho was delicious, except...I had a chunk of very hairy tendon. Really odd, and frankly really gross. I had to stop eating. I believe it was short bits of human hair since I don't think tendon grow black hair. Anyhow, friendly owners and good food for cheap.
author: Nicole L.

description: The vietnamese food here is pretty good here! The owners here is a couple that runs the place. The food they serve is american and vietnamese. I mainly get their vietnamese sandwichs and noodle dishes. Trust me you won't regret getting their Vietnamese dishes. I have never tried there american stuff but maybe next time.
author: Steven C.

description:
The limited options for Vietnamese food in the SOMA and Potrero Hill areas are disappointing.  So, it was by chance that my wife and I were out running errands when I pulled up the ol' m.yelp.com and searched for "pho."  Sunrise was right down the street and it had a good rating, so I figured we'd try it out.

Sure, from the outside, it looks like a hole-in-the-wall, but the inside is quite large and the food was fantastic, especially for the price.  It was a little skimpy on the meat in the pho, but the really nice young guy working the counter made up for it.

We are definitely going to be back.  Next time we go for the Vietnamese sandwiches...
author: Patrick C.

description: This place serves up some mean Pho Ga! It was fresh, tasty, priced right, and the best part was the people who work there are really nice and make you feel really at home. This will be my new stop for lunch time PHO!
author: Jill T.

description:
I had the number 33 which was supposed to flank steak with raw beef.
It was pretty good portion but short on the meat. Price was average for what I got.
Food was good not amazing, but it was close to my office so I can't complain too much.

If you work near by and have a hankering for some pho this place will do the trick.
They have a lot of other stuff that looked good but i haven't eaten it yet. 
I will be back.
author: Jay S.

description: I always come here for my favorite fast ready made to go items during lunch, a choice of beef, pork, chicken or tofu fresh spring rolls and a choice of their pork or chicken banh mi sandwiches for under 10 dollars. In and out in less than a few minutes, even when there is a short line to order at the counter. The owner is always at the cashier to greet you and is fast to get your order promptly ready.
author: Wolfy W.

description: You know this place already; you might even have one down the street from you: a so-so lunch spot that tries to offer everything--hamburgers and ph aren't really a natural combination--but doesn't really do a good job with any of them. You go not because of the varied cuisine or the cafeteria ambiance; you just want something filling quick and keep an eye on the prices rather than the dishes. Basically it's an establishment for feeding, not dining.
author: Steven L.

description:
Fave new lunch spot in SOMA! 

Thanks to Sunrise I'm officially obsessed w/ Vietnamese sandwiches and want to eat them everyday. 

After a few months of the same old boring food for lunch I checked yelp for Vietnamese food near the office. Sunrise is just a few blocks away and it is a gem! So far I've only had the sandwich & the spring rolls - both are fresh and delicious and should not be passed up. 

When I was in there for lunch (again!) today I noticed the pho - wow! It looks sooo good. I just kept staring at it, which was rude b/c the guy who was eating it started to look uncomfortable. I'll try that tomorrow so I don't stare at anyone elses again.
author: Samantha A.

description:
Number 15: Pork + imperial rolls +vermicelli
I had been craving this all week every since Little Saigon.  Having come here before I remembered #15 to be little tastefuls dancing in my mouth.  I tried coming here on Sunday afternoon, and it was closed, so I tried again Friday noontime.  It was pretty packed for a dingy looking place.  I got #15 but was left unsatisfied.  The imperial rolls were so disgusting I could barely eat one roll.  They were deep fried and the wrapping bubbled up like pork rinds.  They were chewy and crunchy at the same time, pretty sure there was left over crud in the deep fryer that stuck to my rolls.  The pork was pretty tasty. But come on, if you serve vietnamese try to get this one right.
author: Skye W.

description:
I have walked by this place so many times over the years.  I walked in randomly the other day thinking I could probably get a low carb meal of Vietnamese BBQ chicken or pork.  I was right on!

I ordered the BBQ pork with egg and salad, and instead of the rice, they gave me extra salad.  It was delicious, low carb (especially if you don't use the sweet vinegar sauce) and it hit the spot! It was maybe a dollar or two more expensive than it should have been, but its ok, the restaurant is clean, the service is fast and very friendly and it was worth it.  Great lunch time spot!
author: Nilu r.

description: Not great, but Pretty good Vietnamese sandwiches.  The tofu they use for the veggie sandwich is yummy!!!  Kind of an expensive Vietnamese sandwich (I am used paying next to nothing for them down south).  Awesome place if you are on the run as they are pretty quick.
author: Vinh N.
